TopicTitle: What is a "Moon to Moon Backflip Orbit"?

Articles.Content:
I read about this manovuer in an orbiter forum. It seems to be neccesary for a periodic Kerbin to mun transfer Orbit.

So can anyone explain what a Moon to Moon Backflip Orbit is, or a 'backflip orbit' in general?

You probably want to see this paper: http://cbboff.org/UCBoulderCourse/documents/LunarCyclerPaper.pdf

I don\'t understand the rationale for this in real life, though. Unless maybe as a way to stream material from Moon to Earth (not the opposite).

Thanks a lot, that is exactly what i looked for!

Look in this thread:

http://kerbalspaceprogram.com/forum/index.php?topic=8357.0

So you might understand why i need it.

I am going do try such a thing on the weekend, hope my english skills(not my native language) are high enough to undestand the paper.
It\'s useful if you want to go more than once. Your launch vehicle can be tiny if they can hitch a ride on the cycler station instead of having to bring all the life support plumbing every time.

It\'s useful if you want to go more than once. Your launch vehicle can be tiny if they can hitch a ride on the cycler station instead of having to bring all the life support plumbing every time.

But it must also be able to bring you back if the docking fails for any reason (excess delta-V, contingency life support.)

On a short trip like the one to the Moon, is there much difference?

To Mars, well, now we\'re talking.
